lesson.title: Problem Identification
lesson.summary: This lesson covers how to make sure that you are solving the right problems by understanding the market, the user, and business goals to identify opportunities. There really is no shortage of problems that could be solved-- but one of the hardest things to do is decide what not to solve.

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Lesson Overview

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text:
In this lesson, we’ll cover the following topics:
- Identifying Opportunities
- Understanding the Market
- The Target User
- Total Addressable Market
- Creating & Evaluating Hypotheses
- Creating a business case

atoms.title: Learning Objectives
atoms.text:
At the end of this lesson, you’ll be able to:
- Identify problems that are worthwhile to solve
- Understand the market through research
- Identify your target user and build user personas
- Calculate the total addressable market (TAM) for your product
- Calculate the return on investment (ROI) for solving a problem
- Define hypotheses about your product that need to be validated
- Test your hypotheses by putting them in front of users 
- Understand the components required to build a business case

atoms.title: Glossary
atoms.text:
## Glossary
| Term | Definition |
| ----------- | ----------- |
| Efficiency gain | Something that results in a process being less expensive to complete (shorter amount of time, less money, etc). |
| TAM | Total Addressable Market. A measure of the revenue opportunity for a product. |
| ARPU | Average Revenue per User. The average amount of revenue you receive for each user you have, usually measured by year. |
| ROI | Return On Investment. The ratio between the net profit and amount of investment. A high ROI indicates more impact with less effort. |
| Payback period | The amount of time that it takes for a product to recoup the initial investment required to build it |
| Focus group | A small group of people you can present concepts to in order to see how they react. Generally this will be a diverse group of people and you will have specific questions you’d like to get their feedback on.  |
| Target User | A representation of a group of users with shared characteristics. |

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Identifying Opportunities

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L2 02 Finding The Right Problem To Solve
Recap
atoms.text: Finding the right problem to solve is critical for the success of your product! If you aren’t focusing on the right problems, your product will fail. This is something that both big and small companies struggle with. You’ll have to work through constraints and tradeoffs

atoms.title: Viable Product
atoms.caption: The best product opportunities solve user problems and meet business goals

question.prompt: Why is it important to identify the right problems to solve?

answers.text: Engineers have varying interests in different problems

question.prompt: What are the things that you have control over when building a product?

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text:
You can start to identify which problems to solve by looking at:
- Market Research
- User Research
- Product Data
- Support Data
- Efficiency gains

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Understanding the Market

atoms.title: Recap
atoms.text: Understanding the market is critical to building successful products. Some markets are better than others. And some products do a better job than others. You’ll want to make sure that your product satisfies the needs of the market.

question.prompt: True or false: Product/market fit means being in a good market with a product that can satisfy that market.

complex_prompt.text: Match the scenarios to things that represent product/market fit or no product/market fit

concepts.text: Hard to keep up with demand

atoms.title: Markets
atoms.caption: Size, growth, and cost of acquisition are factors to consider

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text:
Understanding the market allows you to focus on solving the right problem. Keep in mind that some markets are better than others.

- Size: How many people have this problem?
- Growth: Is the size of the market increasing?
- Acquisition: How much does it cost to acquire customers?

To better understand the market, you’ll want to talk to your users and customers. But before you do, you can look at some of these things to get more familiarity with the market:
- Online research
- Headlines & News
- Similar products
- Trends
 - Mary Meeker’s Internet Trends
 - Google Trends

atoms.title: further research
atoms.text:
## Further Readings

* [Mary Meeker’s Internet Trends](https://www.bondcap.com/report/itr19/)

* [12 Things about Product/Market Fit](https://a16z.com/2017/02/18/12-things-about-product-market-fit/)

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Exercise: Industry Trends

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L2 04 Exercise - Industry Trends
Summary
atoms.text:
Imagine that the team is interested in building a product to help people better track their fitness and improve their health over time. Spend a little bit of time doing some research to better understand current trends in the fitness tracking market. 

Here are some questions to get you started:
- What benefits does improving fitness provide?
- What products are already in the market?
- How much do people spend on health/fitness?
- What are the different ways to deliver fitness tracking? 
 - What are the pros and cons?

atoms.title: industry task
tasks: Do some online research to identify the benefits of improving fitness
Identify at least 5 fitness tracking/improvement products that are already in the market
Do some online research to identify how much money people spend on health & fitness
Do some online research to identify different ways that fitness tracking products could be built and delivered, along with their associated pros and cons.
Jot down your thoughts in the boxes below

question.title: Research
question.text: What benefits does improving fitness provide?

question.title: Research
question.text: What products are already in the market? Identify at least 5 products and give a high level overview of each

question.title: Research
question.text: How much money do people spend on health/fitness?

question.title: Research
question.text: What are different ways that fitness tracking products could be built and delivered? Make sure to list out their associated pros and cons.

question.title: Scratchpad
question.text: Use this textbox for any other thoughts or observations you have while researching

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Solution: Industry Trends

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L2 05 Industry Trends - Solution
Summary
atoms.text:
## Benefits
- Controls weight
- Combats health conditions & diseases
- Improves mood
- Boosts energy
- Sleep better

## Existing Products
- Smartwatches
- Apps
- Smart Ring

## Spending
- $155 / mo
- $1,860 / yr

| Category | Amount |
| ----------- | ----------- |
| Supplements | $56 |
| Clothing | $35 |
| Gym | $33 |
| Meal Plans | $17 |
| Trainers | $14 |

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Target User

atoms.title: Recap
atoms.text: Identifying a target user is important, because it makes it very clear who you are building the product for. Oftentimes, a problem will best be solved in different ways for different types of users. Identifying a target user creates focus and lets you focus on solving the needs of that specific target user.

atoms.title: Calculators
atoms.caption: You would build a different calculator for a grade schooler vs. a scientist

question.prompt: True or false: Your target user is a specific individual user you are targeting

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text: Your target user represents a set of users with shared characteristics, like demographics, motivations, goals, and frustrations, who are likely interested in your product. To identify your target user, you will need to talk to your users and do market research,

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
## Further Readings

* [Are You Ready to Change Your Target Customer?](https://hbr.org/2019/03/are-you-ready-to-change-your-target-customer)

* [How to Define Your Target Market: A Guide to Audience Research](https://blog.hootsuite.com/target-market/)

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Exercise: Target User

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L2 07 Exercise - Target User
Summary
atoms.text:
Given the market research that you’ve done so far, create 3 user personas for a fitness tracker. Keep in mind, that in the real world you would also want to make sure that you get data from real users through interviews or surveys before building any personas. For each persona, create a name and some information about them. Also include their frustrations and goals.

Then, we’ll regroup and walk through the examples that I created

question.title: Target User Persona 1
question.text: Create a target user persona. Make sure to include the user’s name, a quote, their description, frustrations, & goals)

answer.text: Nice work! Continue on to your second persona.

answer.text: Great job! Two down, one more to go...

question.text: Create a target user persona. Make sure to include the user’s name, a quote, their description, frustrations, & goals)

answer.text: Nice work creating your 3 target user personas. Check out the ones that I created in the solution video.

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Solution Target User

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L2 08 Target User - Solution
user 1
atoms.caption: Meet John-- our new year resolution user

atoms.title: user 2

atoms.title: user 3
atoms.caption: Meet Chris-- our avid runner who wants to beat his record

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Total Addressable Market

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L2 09 Total Addressable Market
Recap
atoms.text:
TAM, or total addressable market, is a measure of the revenue opportunity for a product.
Keep in mind that TAM is not a measure of your revenue or future revenue. Instead, it allows you to understand the size of the market if you had 100% of the market. A larger TAM indicates a larger opportunity, with more demand for a particular product. However, just because there’s a large TAM does not mean that a product is guaranteed to be successful… 
There are lots of other factors that will come into play, like competition.

question.prompt: True or false: TAM is a way to predict your future sales

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text:
TAM = Average revenue per user X  total number of potential users in the market

There are several approaches to calculating TAM:
- Top Down
 - You start with a high level view of the economy, and then narrow that down based on factors like demographics. For example, you usually will start will everyone in the world and narrow down that audience to people who are interested in your product.
- Bottoms Up
 - This involves using known data points that you have (data from early customers and sales) that you could extrapolate to represent a larger market opportunity. For example, if you are already selling a product in one region and were considering selling it globally.
- Value Theory
 - Generally used for new product categories where you don’t have much information to base estimates on. This involves conducting market research to understand how much people would pay for your product and how many potential customers you have.

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
## Further Readings

* [How to calculate your total addressable market and make a great TAM slide for investors](https://www.forentrepreneurs.com/calculating-tam/)

atoms.title: Header

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L2 10 Total Addressable Market Exercise
tam exercise
atoms.caption: Calculate the TAM for streaming media services in the US

atoms.title: TAM Tasks
tasks: Use online sources to quickly research streaming media services
Identify the potential number of people that can use the product
Identify an estimate for the cost of the product

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Solution: TAM

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L2 11 Total Addressable Market Exercise - Solution
TAM solution
atoms.caption: TAM for streaming in the US is $15.6B

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## ROI

atoms.title: Recap
atoms.text: ROI is a way to measure the efficiency of an investment (like deciding to build a new product or feature). Understanding and calculating ROI for different problems will help you to understand where to focus your team’s time in order to have the biggest impact.

atoms.title: roi image
atoms.caption: ROI is the ratio between the return and investment

atoms.title: roi quiz
atoms.caption: Use the information in this table to answer the quizzes below

complex_prompt.text: Using the data in the table above., match each problem to its ROI

question.prompt: Which problem has the shortest payback period?

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text: Calculating ROI and payback periods are two important tools to help you understand if it makes sense to solve a problem. Projects with positive ROIs will cover the investment required to build the product… Projects with negative ROIs will not and won’t make sense to pursue. Calculating the payback period allows you to understand how long it will take before the product recoups the upfront investment required to build it.

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Creating Hypotheses

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L2 13 Creating A Hypothesis
Recap
atoms.text:
Before you build a product… you want to be sure that it will be successful. You can create hypotheses to make sure that your assumptions about your product  are correct-- and that you are solving a real problem for real people. After creating your hypotheses, you can test them to see if they are true / still accurate in the real world.

Your hypotheses should be based on:
- Customer needs
- Your solution
- Differentiation
- Value

question.prompt: Which of the following are things that you should consider when creating a hypotheses::

answers.text: Does our solution solve the problem?
How much will people pay for this product?
What could increase people’s willingness to pay?

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Evaluating Hypotheses

atoms.title: ND036 C1 L2 14 Evaluating A Hypothesis
Recap
atoms.text:
You can test and evaluate your hypotheses in several different ways…
- User interviews
- Focus groups
- Surveys
- Design sprint

If you find that:
- You are not addressing a customer need
- Your solution isn’t providing value
- Your product isn’t differentiated enough
- There’s no willingness to pay…

**Stop**. It’s not worth pursuing this idea in its current form because you won’t have product/market fit. You should go back and tweak which customer you are focusing on… or your solution.. Or pricing model.

question.prompt: True or false: It’s helpful to show users a prototype when validating your hypotheses

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text: Before you build a product… you want to be sure that it will be successful. Creating hypotheses around the problem, your solution, differentiation, and value and then testing them is a good strategy to make sure that you find product/market fit.

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
## Further Readings

* [Product development through hypotheses](https://www.etventure.com/blog/product-development-through-hypotheses-formulating-hypotheses/)

* [Customer Development with Steve Blank: Hypothesis Testing](https://www.startups.com/library/expert-advice/customer-development-steve-blank-hypothesis-testing)

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Building a Business Case

atoms.title: Recap
atoms.text:
A business case answers the question: “Why should the company do/invest in this?”

The goal is to convince sponsors/stakeholders to approve the project. You won’t always need to go to this level of detail for all projects, like a new feature in an existing product. For smaller projects, the PRD will likely have enough detail. But for an entirely brand new product, you will need to be able to justify the larger investment. Is it worth continuing this project?

A business case should include:
- Business problem
- Benefits
- Costs
- Risks
- Possible solutions
- Timeline
- Competition

question.prompt: True or false: A business case describes how the product will work in detail
True or false: Every feature must have an in depth business case.

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text:
For new product investments it’s important to build a business case, which answers the question: “Does it make sense to build this?”

Your business case should be organized into the following sections:

**Executive Summary**
The Executive summary summarizes the entire document, including the recommendation. You want to make sure that it has enough detail that if it’s the only thing people read they will understand the justifications for building the product. It’s also the first thing people read and usually the last thing you will write to make sure that everything is cohesive.

**Problem Statement**
The Problem Statement explains the problem you are trying to solve, as well as the associated goals. It should also clearly link the problem back to the business strategy and goals.

**Analysis of Product Opportunity**
In the Analysis of Product Opportunity section, you discuss the merits of why solving the problem is important. You’ll usually want to touch on the cost of the problem and the size of the opportunity. Additionally, you can discuss what would happen if you didn’t solve the problem.

**Possible Solutions**
In the Possible Solutions section, you will describe the potential solutions to the problem. For each solution, you should discuss benefits, cost, timeline, and risks.

**Recommended Approach**
And finally in the Recommended Approach section, you put forward your recommendation for which solution is the best and why.



Other tips to keep in mind:
- Tailor it to your audience
- Shorter is better
- Make it interesting
- Demonstrate business value

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
## Further Readings

* [Sample Business Case](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1002/9781119198758.app1)

* [5 Steps to Write a Solid Business Case](https://www.chasegroup.com.au/five-steps-to-develop-a-solid-business-case)

atoms.title: Header
atoms.text: ## Lesson Recap

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text:
You’ve reached the end of the Problem Identification lesson. We covered the following topics:
- Identifying Opportunities
- Understanding the Market
- The Target User
- Total Addressable Market
- Creating & Evaluating Hypotheses
- Creating a business case


At this point, you should be able to:
- Identify problems that are worthwhile to solve
- Understand the market through research
- Identify your target user and build user personas
- Calculate the total addressable market (TAM) for your product
- Calculate the return on investment (ROI) for solving a problem
- Define hypotheses about your product that need to be validated
- Test your hypotheses by putting them in front of users 
- Understand the components required to build a business case
